verses.text: A copy of an epistle, which Jeremie sent unto them which were to be led captives into Babylon by the king of the Babylonians, to certify them, as it was commanded him of God.
Because of the sins which ye have committed before God, ye shall be led \add away\add* captives into Babylon by Nabuchodonosor king of the Babylonians.
So when ye be come unto Babylon, ye shall remain there many years, and for a long season, namely, seven generations: and after that I will bring you away peaceably from thence.
Now shall ye see in Babylon gods of silver, and of gold, and of wood, borne upon shoulders, which cause the nations to fear.
Beware therefore that ye in no wise be like to strangers, neither be ye afraid of them, when ye see the multitude before \add them\add* and behind them, worshipping them.
But say ye in \add your\add* hearts, O Lord, we must worship thee.
For mine angel is with you, and \add I my\add*self caring for your souls.
As for their tongue, it is polished by the workman, and they themselves \add are\add* gilded and laid over with silver; yet are they but false, and cannot speak.
And taking gold, as it were for a virgin that loves to go gay, they make crowns for the heads of their gods.
Sometimes also the priests convey from their gods gold and silver, and bestow \add it\add* upon themselves.
Yea, they will give thereof to the common harlots, and deck them as men with garments, \add being\add* gods of silver, and gods of gold, and wood.
Yet cannot these \add gods\add* save themselves from rust and moths, though they be covered with purple raiment.
They wipe their faces because of the dust of the temple, when there is much upon them.
And he that cannot put to death one that offendeth him holdeth a sceptre, as \add though he were\add* a judge of the country.
He hath also in his right hand a dagger and an axe: but cannot deliver himself from war and thieves.
Whereby they are known not to be gods: therefore fear them not.

For like as a vessel that a man useth is nothing worth when it is broken; \add even\add* so it is with their gods: when they be set up in the temple, their eyes be full of dust through the feet of them that come in.

And as the doors are made sure on every side upon him that offendeth the king, as being committed to suffer death: \add even so\add* the priests make fast their temples with doors, with locks, and bars, lest \add their gods\add* be spoiled with robbers.
They light \add them\add* candles, yea, more than for themselves, whereof they cannot see one.

They are as one of the beams of the temple, yet they say their hearts are gnawed upon \add by\add* things creeping out of the earth; \add and\add* when they eat them and their clothes, they feel \add it\add* not.
Their faces \add are\add* blacked through the smoke that \add comes\add* out of the temple.
Upon their bodies and heads sit bats, swallows, and birds, and the cats also.
By this you may know that they are no gods: therefore fear them not.
Notwithstanding the gold that is about them to make them beautiful, except they wipe off the rust, they will not shine: for neither when they were molten did they feel \add it\add*.
\add The things\add* wherein there is no breath are bought for a most high price.
They are borne upon shoulders, having no feet, whereby they declare unto men that they be nothing worth.

They also that serve them are ashamed: for if they fall to the ground at any time, \add they\add* cannot rise up \add again\add* of themselves: neither, if one set them upright, can they move of themselves: neither, if they be bowed down, can they make themselves straight: but they set gifts before them, as unto dead \add men\add*.

As for the things that are sacrificed unto them, their priests sell and abuse; in like manner their wives lay up \add part\add* thereof in salt; but unto the poor and impotent they give nothing of \add it\add*.
Menstruous women and women in childbed eat their sacrifices: by these \add things\add* ye may know that they are no gods: fear them not.
For how can they be called gods? because women set \add meat\add* before the gods of silver, gold, and wood.
And the priests sit in their temples, having \add their\add* clothes rent, and \add their\add* heads and beards shaven, and nothing upon their heads.
They roar and cry before their gods, as men \add do\add* at the feast when one is dead.
The priests also take off their garments, and clothe their wives and children.
Whether \add it be\add* evil \add that\add* one doeth unto them, or good, they are not able to recompense \add it:\add* they can neither set up a king, nor put \add him\add* down.
In like manner, they can neither give riches nor money: though a man make a vow unto them, and keep \add it\add* not, they will not require \add it\add*.
They can save no man from death, neither deliver the weak from the mighty.
They cannot restore a blind man to \add his\add* sight, nor help \add any\add* man in \add his\add* distress.
They can shew no mercy to the widow, nor do good to the fatherless.
\add Their gods\add* of wood, and \add which are\add* overlaid with gold and silver, are like the stones that be \add hewn\add* out of the mountain: they that worship them shall be confounded.
How should \add a man\add* then think and say that they are gods? When even the Chaldeans themselves dishonour them.
Who if they shall see \add one\add* dumb that cannot speak, they bring \add him\add*, and intreat Bel that \add he\add* may speak, as though he were able to understand.
Yet they cannot understand \add this\add* themselves, and leave them: for they have no knowledge.

The women also with cords about them, sitting in the ways, burn bran for perfume: but if any of them, drawn by some that passeth by, lie \add with him\add*, she reproacheth \add her\add* fellow, that she was not thought as worthy as herself, nor her cord broken.
Whatsoever is done among them is false: how may it then be thought or said that they are gods?
They are made of carpenters and goldsmiths: they can be nothing else than the workmen will have them to be.
And they themselves that made them can never continue long; how should then the \add things\add* that are made of them be gods?
For they left lies and reproaches to them that come after.
For when there cometh \add any\add* war or plague upon them, the priests consult with themselves, where they may be hidden with them.
How then cannot \add men\add* perceive that they be no gods, which can neither save themselves from war, nor from plague?
For seeing they be \add but\add* of wood, and overlaid with silver and gold, it shall be known hereafter that they are false:
\add and\add* it shall manifestly appear to all nations and kings that they are no gods, but the works of menâ€™s hands, and \add that\add* there is no work of God in them.
Who then may \add not\add* know that they are no gods?
For neither can they set up a king in the land, nor give rain unto men.
Neither can they judge their own cause, nor redress a wrong, being unable: for \add they are\add* as crows between heaven and earth.

Whereupon when fire falleth upon the house of gods of wood, or laid over with gold or silver, their priests will flee \add away\add*, and escape; but they themselves shall be burnt asunder like beams.
Moreover they cannot withstand \add any\add* king or enemies: how can it then be thought or said that they be gods?
Neither are \add those\add* gods of wood, and laid over with silver or gold, able to escape either from thieves or robbers.
Whose gold, and silver, and garments wherewith they are clothed, they that are strong do take, and go away withal: neither are they able to help themselves.

Therefore \add it is\add* better to be a king that sheweth his power, or \add else\add* a profitable vessel in a house, which the owner shall have use of, than \add such\add* false gods; or to be a door in a house, to keep such \add things\add* safe as be therein, than \add such\add* false gods; or a pillar of wood in a palace, than \add such\add* false gods.
For sun, moon, and stars, being bright, and sent to do \add their\add* offices, are obedient.
In like manner the lightning when it breaketh forth is easy to be seen; and after the same \add manner\add* the wind bloweth in every country.
And when God commandeth the clouds to go over the whole world, they do as they are bidden.
And the fire sent from above to consume hills and woods doeth as it is commanded: but these are like unto them neither in shew nor power.
Wherefore it is neither to be supposed nor said that they are gods, seeing they are able neither to judge causes, nor to do good unto men.
Knowing therefore that they are no gods, fear them not.
For they can neither curse nor bless kings:
neither can they shew signs in the heavens among the heathen, nor shine as the sun, nor give light as the moon.
The beasts are better than they: for they can get under a covert, and help themselves.
It is then by no means manifest unto us that they are gods: therefore fear them not.
For as a scarecrow in a garden of cucumbers keepeth nothing: so are their gods of wood, and laid over with silver and gold.
And likewise their gods of wood, and laid over with silver and gold, are like to a white thorn in an orchard, that every bird sitteth upon; as also to a dead body, that is cast into the dark.
And you shall know them to be no gods by the bright purple that rotteth upon them: and they themselves afterward shall be eaten, and shall be a reproach in the country.
Better therefore \add is\add* the just man that hath none idols: for he shall be far from reproach.
